section.title: Introduction
section.t: When the ICE (RFC 5245) and TURN (RFC 5766) is used in a endpoint as a firewall/NAT traversal mechanism the TURN relay can also be used to measure bandwidth and latency prior to call setup.

In normal ICE behavior the client first send a message (allocate request) to the TURN server to allocate a RELAY address. This address can be used by the endpoint to receive media from other endpoints. The media stream is then received by the TURN server and then relayed back to the endpoint behind the fw/NAT. For security reasons the endpoint must first set the correct permissions on the TURN server to only allow media from remote participants he wants to talk to (Addresses taken from the SIP SDP offer/answer exhange) . The endpoint will also learn it RFLX address on the fw/NAT when talking to the TURN server.

section.title: Overview of Operation
section.t: Prior to the call (On registering or any convenient time) the endpoint can measure bandwidth and latency between the endpoint and TURN server.

The agent allocates a TURN Relay port on its designated TURN server as described in RFC XXX. In the process the agent will alos learn the outmost NAT address. This is called the reflexive address. For more information se the section regarding candidate discovery in ICE RFCZZZ.
The agent must set the permissions on the allocated realay port as describen in TURN RFCYYY section xx, to allow traffic from the discovered RFLX adress.

Send packets to the allocated Relay port on the TURN server. The packets will be forarded back to the agent in a data inidication pacaket- Se TURN RFCXXX sectionYY for details on how the ternserver can relay packets back to the allocating agent. 5. Special payload packets arrive at TURN server on the RELAY port and will be sent back to endpoint on the TURN tunnel opened up by the initial allocate request.
